awd_titl_txt: Hazards SEES: Bridging Information, Uncertainty, and Decision-Making in Hurricanes using an Interdisciplinary Perspective
awd_abstract_narration:
In order to respond more effectively to hurricanes, emergency managers need better decision support tools that account for the response of populations to uncertainty in hurricane forecasts, as well as the consequences of household decisions on key infrastructure systems.  For example, Hurricane Sandy is estimated to have caused more than $70 billion in losses, and Hurricane Katrina caused significant loss of life; in both cases, the situation was made worse due to chaos in key transportation systems. We are addressing this need by developing next generation data-driven tools for capturing and mitigating uncertainty in hazards such as hurricanes.  Using data from various sources, we are developing new understanding of household level behaviors, how individuals and agencies process uncertainty at different instances of the hurricane onset, and the consequences of the household decisions on citywide traffic congestion. We are developing data-driven modeling, social science, and computational systems science approaches leveraging recent advancements in data gathering in order to improve the effectiveness of evacuations and save lives. 

We are collecting novel data through post-hurricane mail surveys, personal interviews, web experiments, social media, and process tracing software and developing new integrative scientific approaches to modeling household level behaviors and social network effects across households and other stakeholders. Using these data and methods, we are modeling evacuation logistics for hurricanes, using computational sciences as a supporting discipline. We are thus providing a holistic approach to characterize, measure, and analyze uncertainty in various aspects of hurricane evacuation modeling, social networks, household decision-making, and stochastic traffic modeling.  The advances in knowledge from this project will impact multiple disciplines including emergency management, complex systems science, transportation engineering, and computational sciences.   Our research outcomes will assist emergency managers and agencies to anticipate transportation and sheltering needs and to improve community planning prior to hurricanes by integrating household behavior information with traffic simulation. These improvements will lead to safer and more effective evacuations at lower cost, reduced stress, and most importantly, with less loss of life.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF project developed state-of-the-art models and decision-support tools for better evacuation planning by identifying, measuring, accounting for, and mitigating uncertainty in the evacuation process and providing better information to households.  The research outcomes were developed based on interdisciplinary collaborations between researchers from social science, engineering, and computer science. The project has significant societal impacts and will make hurricane evacuations efficient. As shown in Figure 1 (see attachment), this project involves collecting and analyzing novel data, developing new integrative scientific approaches to modeling household behaviors and social network effects across households and other stakeholders, and modeling evacuation traffic for hurricanes.

The key outcomes from this project were:

Intellectual Merit

1.       Post-hurricane household mailing data were collected to model uncertainty and the household decision process. Besides this, several novel datasets were collected and explored: phone interview data was collected from 20 Florida county emergency managers to understand the decision-making processes involved in making hurricane evacuation orders; geotagged tweets were collected to infer aggregated evacuation decisions and corresponding demographic statistics; online information-certainty survey data were collected to understand evacuation decision process.

2.     Five interconnected household behavioral decision models were developed to predict household evacuation decisions. These decisions involve whether or not to evacuate, evacuation destination, accommodation type, departure time, and the number of used vehicles. The result is an accurate estimate of evacuation demand, which serves as an input for traffic simulation.

3.     A high-fidelity parallelizable traffic simulation for evacuation, called A-RESCUE 3.0, was developed to bridge the household evacuation decision-making and its policy implications. The first version was developed in 2017. The second version developed in 2019 had major performance upgrades by introducing parallelization achieved via periodic network partitioning and optimal load balancing. The third version further improved the scalability and introduced a user-friendly web-based visualization interface (VI) to display simulation information, as shown in Figure 2 in the attachment. The detailed description of A-RESCUE can be found in  https://umnilab.github.io/HSEES_doc/.

 

Broader Impacts 

1.       Two PhD dissertations, two MS theses, nine journal articles, and ten conference papers were published based on the collected data and the developed models.

2.       More than 13 graduate students across three universities and more than 5 undergraduate students were trained in the project across engineering, social science and computational sciences.

3.      A seminar series called ?Urban Transformations Seminar Series? was developed by Dr. Ukkusuri in Spring 2021. More than 10 speakers from around the world were invited to present the latest research in urban systems resilience. Hazards research was an important component of this seminar series and several speakers discussed community level issues related to evacuation, citizen engagement, and metrics for measuring vulnerability using innovative datasets. Several students and researchers participated in the seminar series which was followed by a discussion session where students were able to share their work with the speakers.

4.     A new graduate course Transport Risk and Evacuation was developed by Dr. Murray-Tuite in Fall 2019. This course introduced students to models used for modeling hazards and different aspects of evacuation including (1) whether to evacuate or stay, (2) destination choice, (3) accommodation choice, (4) number of vehicles to bring, and (5) departure timing. Students applied this knowledge to develop evacuation demand for the town of Edisto Beach, SC, which they then used with traffic simulation tools to estimate evacuation time estimates. Six students from two different departments enrolled in the course.

5.       A course on Disaster Resilience and Society was developed by Dr. Ukkusuri and Dr. Lee developed in Spring 2018 and offered it twice to undergraduate students from across the campus. The course was offered two times ? Fall 2018 and Fall 2019. Students learned the basics of the disaster life cycle, decision-making process, and strengths and pitfalls of current data collection methods for hazards-related research.

6.       An instructional material (Lee, Wittrock, & Benedict, 2019) was published to facilitate students? understanding of network measures, including different types of node centrality, shortest paths, cliques, and communities, and their implications for information flow in groups or organizations. The article introduced a game in which students solve a company mystery by exchanging information clues with other students based on an imposed communication network configuration. Examples of network configuration, data sets, and a script that uses R?s igraph package were included in the publication.
